SRGC Asia

Sarina's Rhythmic Gymnastic

About us

There are many types of gymnastics comprising Acrobatics, Artistic Gymnastics, General Gymnastics, Rhythmic Gymnastics and Trampoline.

Rhythmic gymnastics is a discipline performed mostly by women, combining agility, artistry and grace accompanied by expressive interpretation of musics, while manipulating different types of apparatus.

History

Started as an illustration of expression through movement using rhythm and dance founded by Jean Georges Noverre and Francois Delsarte towards the end of the 19th and early 20th centuries, Rhythmic gymnastics was recognised be the Federation of International Gymnastics (FIG) in 1962 and was subsequently added as an Olympic sport in 1984.

Sarina Sundara Rajah, Head Coach

Gold Medalist, 1998 Commonwealth Games

Gold Medalist, 2001 SEA Games

Sarina Sundara Rajah started her journey as a rhythmic gymnast fairly late at the age of 12. While the inception of Sarina’s career began later than most, Sarina had been a decorated rhythmic gymnast in Malaysia and won a gold medal from the 1998 Commonwealth Games and a gold medal from the 2001 SEA Games in Kuala Lumpur.

Inspired by Malaysian gymnast Farrah Hani Imran back when she was a child, Sarina sets herself to nurture young athletes, provide them with necessary support to build them into successful athletes. She started Sarina’s Rhythmic Gymnastics Club (SRGC) to fulfill this purpose and has been coaching for 10+ years, weekly across various schools in the Klang Valley.

FAQs

Age requirement

Training programmes are for children aged 4 years old and above (girls only) for all aptitude, experience and levels.

Children must be comfortable and independent to be in the training venue without a parent/guardian for an extended period of time, are able to interact in groups and toilet trained.

Training, Recognition & Accreditation

The training programmes are designed in accordance to the National Classification Programme and endorsed by the Malaysian Gymnastics Federation (MGF).
